reviewText:
The game starts off very slowly.  You're the only employee in your pizza business, so it's your job to both make the pizza and deliver it.  You choose your toppings (very limited at first), manually place them on the pizza, then hop in the car and WASD deliver it to a green area in a city.  You have an ample time limit to deliver in.  It seems like the only danger is flipping your car if you brush up against a curb during a turn, which automatically forfeits your delivery.  Other cars driving on the roads will stop if you cut in front of them, so it seems like you would only hit them if you were trying, or were very reckless.

After you've delivered a few pizzas, you get to buy some upgrades.  First toppings (olives, bell peppers, ham, etc), then sides (pasta, garlic bread), and eventually shop employees.  You can upgrade to hire chefs, drivers, and janitors.

This game's speed is absolutely exponential.  Where the pizza deliveries initially drag on, once you make your first hires, it starts to explode.  Suddenly the game is about pizza shop management instead of pizza order fulfillment.  You can then unlock additional shops and regions, and you can keep tabs on your competition's stores.  You can hire managers to watch over your employees' productivity and wellbeing, then hire regional managers to supervise those managers.

It was almost too hard to keep up after I made the poor choice of unlocking all the regions at once and opening a store in each - expansion strategy is definitely important in this game.

You'll have employees who quit because they're overworked, along with kitchen fires, political decisions, mafia proposals, etc. that show up in a small event feed in the upper right hand corner.

I'm definitely not done playing this game, but I thought I'd jump in and provide a review while the sale is going on.

As for my opinion: yes, definitely buy this if you like sim games.  The devs are obviously still engaged in improving the game and you should be able to get several hours of play out of it.  However if you lack patience, this may not be the game for you.  There are quite a few pizzas and deliveries to make before the game scales up to the management aspect.

TL;DR - 7.5/10 would recommend, but devs are involved so that number will go up as they respond to comments.  Gotta have patience as your store grows.  Don't run into the curb.  If your employee is slacking, fire them.

Updated as of the new update:
I played about three hours of the newest update and i have to say it is a huge improvement on the old version of the game. I have to say that All of the things that were added and removed were really good changes for the games I will expand on all of this later on in the review. Although I recommended the game earlier this year but just not the price point i can say that just like last time the I would not have paid 15 dollars for this game. But on sale for 10$ or 7.50$ is well worth this type of game.

Pros:
- Driving mini-game has been updated so that you can’t flip the car anymore as easily.
- Creation mini-games stayed the same. (They are good as they are and did not need changed anyways)
- There is no more clicking a button to clean your shop anymore! (Yay this made no since without an applicable mini-game for it or something else)
- The new overview screen. While this is no longer a pizza I can see why this was changed to allow more than a couple of shops to own. I think I saw it’s possible to have up to over like 70-80 shops or so.
- The UI Overhaul! This was a great change because of the old UI had just so much fluff that it made no since to see all of this information when there were not really anything good about this.
-The new manager and employee system. You can have one manager and four employees now. This is also all on the same screen as your shop. It makes it easier for you to view everything you need without having to cover up and important parts of what’s going on.
- The new drag and drop to employees (before managers) for them to get the order. This allows for more player interaction and i had fun sitting there and trying to micromanage some shops until they had managers this time around. I wanted to make sure that no phone call was going unanswered and made it interesting and fun for me to go through all of this.
- Etc... I guess I will expand on more later if I remember any more pros about this game.

Cons
-Like I said previously the price point of the game is still a huge concern. 15$ is still a big price for a game like this. But when a sale goes on for like 7.50$ or 10$ it will be well worth the pickup price for this game.
- I don’t really know about any more cons for me personally but if any arise I will update this review as well.

So I will say that i give this game a solid 8.5/10 for me. If anyone likes a management sim type game this is the game for you. This allows for more of that than anything else. reviewText:
This game is definitely worth it for the price. It's easy to hop in, play, save your game and continue right where you left off later. You start off as a small pizza shop owner having to do all the leg work yourself. You then progress to upgrading your shop to something better, hiring employees, managing their pay, vacation, skill, training, forming different kinds of advertising campaigns to get the best reputation results (when you get more popular, you then have to start being able to juggle 10+ orders per shop being placed at the same time).

Mix that in with the fun random events like the actress outside that you can help or leave to the mob, laundering money for the mafia and later starting a war between the gangs, influencing politics and backing a potential Senator (or later a President), and this game is a breath of fresh air and simply fun to play when you need a break from other standardized (copycat) games (*cough* survival games plaguing early access).

I don't understand the people posting negative reviews about a $13 game they only played for 10-20 minutes. At the beginning it's more about making your customers happy, personally making and delivering the pizzas (and later the wings, breadsticks, subs, and other unlockable items) so you aren't going to be doing pure management up front. I don' t think this game is meant to copy other tycoon games but be a fun simulation of its own, starting from the bottom and working your way to the top.

One thing I do like is that the developers seem to be active and trying to make the game better. You don't see that very often on Steam.

reviewText:
The game starts off very slowly.  You're the only employee in your pizza business, so it's your job to both make the pizza and deliver it.  You choose your toppings (very limited at first), manually place them on the pizza, then hop in the car and WASD deliver it to a green area in a city.  You have an ample time limit to deliver in.  It seems like the only danger is flipping your car if you brush up against a curb during a turn, which automatically forfeits your delivery.  Other cars driving on the roads will stop if you cut in front of them, so it seems like you would only hit them if you were trying, or were very reckless.

After you've delivered a few pizzas, you get to buy some upgrades.  First toppings (olives, bell peppers, ham, etc), then sides (pasta, garlic bread), and eventually shop employees.  You can upgrade to hire chefs, drivers, and janitors.

This game's speed is absolutely exponential.  Where the pizza deliveries initially drag on, once you make your first hires, it starts to explode.  Suddenly the game is about pizza shop management instead of pizza order fulfillment.  You can then unlock additional shops and regions, and you can keep tabs on your competition's stores.  You can hire managers to watch over your employees' productivity and wellbeing, then hire regional managers to supervise those managers.

It was almost too hard to keep up after I made the poor choice of unlocking all the regions at once and opening a store in each - expansion strategy is definitely important in this game.

You'll have employees who quit because they're overworked, along with kitchen fires, political decisions, mafia proposals, etc. that show up in a small event feed in the upper right hand corner.

I'm definitely not done playing this game, but I thought I'd jump in and provide a review while the sale is going on.

As for my opinion: yes, definitely buy this if you like sim games.  The devs are obviously still engaged in improving the game and you should be able to get several hours of play out of it.  However if you lack patience, this may not be the game for you.  There are quite a few pizzas and deliveries to make before the game scales up to the management aspect.

TL;DR - 7.5/10 would recommend, but devs are involved so that number will go up as they respond to comments.  Gotta have patience as your store grows.  Don't run into the curb.  If your employee is slacking, fire them.

reviewText:
This game is definitely worth it for the price. It's easy to hop in, play, save your game and continue right where you left off later. You start off as a small pizza shop owner having to do all the leg work yourself. You then progress to upgrading your shop to something better, hiring employees, managing their pay, vacation, skill, training, forming different kinds of advertising campaigns to get the best reputation results (when you get more popular, you then have to start being able to juggle 10+ orders per shop being placed at the same time).

Mix that in with the fun random events like the actress outside that you can help or leave to the mob, laundering money for the mafia and later starting a war between the gangs, influencing politics and backing a potential Senator (or later a President), and this game is a breath of fresh air and simply fun to play when you need a break from other standardized (copycat) games (*cough* survival games plaguing early access).

I don't understand the people posting negative reviews about a $13 game they only played for 10-20 minutes. At the beginning it's more about making your customers happy, personally making and delivering the pizzas (and later the wings, breadsticks, subs, and other unlockable items) so you aren't going to be doing pure management up front. I don' t think this game is meant to copy other tycoon games but be a fun simulation of its own, starting from the bottom and working your way to the top.

One thing I do like is that the developers seem to be active and trying to make the game better. You don't see that very often on Steam.
